conclusion: The problem involves a conductor rod MN in a spring vibration system, placed on a horizontal smooth rectangular metal guide rail in a uniform magnetic field, with resistors at both ends.
The spring is initially at its natural length, and the conductor rod MN has an initial leftward velocity.
The Joule heat generated on the resistor R between AB is Q, and the task is to find the magnitude of the Ampere force on the rod at the initial moment.
The guide rail ABCD is rectangular, with resistors R at both ends, a spring connected to the left side, and a conductor rod MN placed horizontally on the rail.
The magnetic field is uniform, directed vertically downward, and represented by 'X' symbols in the diagram.
The conductor rod MN is initially at rest relative to the spring, which is at its natural length.
The conductor rod MN is moving to the right due to the spring vibration system.
The conductor rod MN is in a magnetic field, which will induce an electromotive force (EMF) as it moves.
The movement of the conductor rod MN generates a current in the circuit due to the induced EMF.
The Joule heat Q is generated in the resistors R due to the current flowing through the circuit.
The energy transfer involves the conversion of the conductor rod's kinetic energy into Joule heat Q and elastic potential energy in the spring.
The force on the conductor rod MN is due to the magnetic field (Ampere force), the spring force, and the resistance in the circuit.
The Ampere force on the conductor rod is given by \( F_B = BIL \), where \( I \) is the current in the conductor rod.
The spring force on the conductor rod is given by \( F_S = kx \), where \( x \) is the displacement of the conductor rod.
The resistance force on the conductor rod is given by \( F_R = IR \), where \( R \) is the resistance of the conductor rod.
The magnitude of the Ampere force on the rod at the initial moment is \( F_B = BIL \).
